formulaic_mechanics.create_corpora.hexameter 

  1# This code was written by Hope Ranker (https://github.com/epilanthanomai/hexameter/tree/master) 
  2
  3from collections import defaultdict
  4
  5LONG = '+'
  6SHORT = '-'
  7INDETERMINATE = '?' # could be long or short
  8LONG_CORREPTION = 'C' # long and positionally candidate for correption
  9INDETERMINATE_CORREPTION = 'c' # indeterminate length but positionally
 10                               # candidate for correption if long
 11SHORT_SYNIZESIS = ',' # short and positionally candidate for synizesis
 12
 13# these three are not used in input, but are used in output analysis:
 14SKIPPED = '.'
 15FOOT = '|'
 16
 17# A basic hexameter foot has a simplified state diagram something like this:
 18#
 19#                ,----- -L- -----,
 20#   (0) -L- (1) <                 >- (7)
 21#                '- -s- (2) -s- -'
 22#
 23# This diagram ignores important features like indeterminate-length
 24# syllables, correption, and synizesis; those will be added shortly. We
 25# start at state (0) and accept only a long (-L-) syllable, which
 26# transitions us to (1). We may then accept either another long or two
 27# shorts. Either transitions us to (7), either directly (via a -L-) or by
 28# way of (2) (through two -s- transitions). We can chain this five times for
 29# the first five feet of the meter, with each foot starting on the end state
 30# of the last, and then the last foot is a simplified version that accepts a
 31# long followed by any syllable (represented here as -X-):
 32#
 33#   (35) -L- (36) -X- (37)
 34#
 35# To account for syllables in the poem that could be either long or short,
 36# we extend the -L-, -s-, and -X- transitions to accept indeterminate length
 37# syllables. Correption is handled similarly: Either of the correption
 38# candidate syllables defined above could serve as either a -L-, -s-, or -X-
 39# transition.
 40#
 41# Synizesis essentially allows us to fuse certain short syllables together
 42# with a following syllable to produce a long. That means that any -L- or
 43# -X- transition in our simplified diagram above could also be satisfied by
 44# a SHORT_SYNIZESIS syllable followed by any other single syllable. And in
 45# fact this fused syllable may be affected by correption (as in Il. 1.15),
 46# so any -s- transition could be satisfied by a SHORT_SYNIZESIS followed by
 47# a correption candidate. This adds some complexity to the simplified
 48# diagram above. Using -z- for a synizesis transition and -C- for any
 49# transition representing a correptible syllable, the first foot looks like
 50# this:
 51#
 52#                                 ,-------------- -L- --------------,
 53#                                /                                   \
 54#        ,---- -L- ----,        /------------ -z- (4) -X- ------------\
 55#   (0) <               > (1) -<                                       > (7)
 56#        ' -z- (3) -X- '        \  ,--- -s- ---,       ,--- -s- ---,  /
 57#                                '<             > (2) <             >'
 58#                                  '-z- (5) -C-'       '-z- (6) -C-'
 59#
 60# And the sixth foot examds to:
 61#
 62#        ,----- -L- ----,        ,----- -L- ----,
 63#  (35) <                > (36) <                > (37)
 64#        ' -z- (38) -X- '        ' -z- (39) -X- '
 65#
 66# This gets us far, but an unweighted algorithm can't distinguish between a
 67# scan free of any synizesis or correption and a line that contains many of
 68# those exceptions. We want to favor scans with as few of these features as
 69# possible, and so we add a cost to transitions involving synizesis and
 70# correption. Specifically, additional cost/weight is given to the transitions
 71# where LONG_CORREPTION transitions in the -s- group (that is, where correption
 72# occurs), and where SHORT_SYNIZESIS transitions participate in the replacement
 73# of a long syllable. Note that this cost is not applied when a LONG_CORREPTION
 74# transitions along a -L- path: This is the normal case of a long syllable
 75# functioning as a long syllable. The cost is also not applied for an
 76# INDETERMINATE_CORREPTION syllable in any case: This is a syllable that could
 77# be either short or long naturally, and so no correption is necessary to
 78# explain its use as short. Since SHORT_SYNIZESIS is just a short syllable
 79# normally, its transition along a -s- path similarly has no additional cost.
 80# Our machine collects all possible matches and reports each with its cost so
 81# that calling software can report any and all appropriate scansions.
 82#
 83# Note that frequently (~1300 lines, e.g., Il. 1.33) won't scan unless we
 84# scan short syllables as long. Some of these can be explained with a
 85# dropped digamma, but not all of them. In order to provide some sensible
 86# scansion, we allow SHORT_SYLLABLES to fill in for LONG_SYLLABLES. We give
 87# this an arbitrarily high cost so that the path is only taken as a last
 88# resort.
 89
 90LONG_SYLLABLES = [ LONG, INDETERMINATE, LONG_CORREPTION, INDETERMINATE_CORREPTION ]
 91SHORT_SYLLABLES = [ SHORT, INDETERMINATE, INDETERMINATE_CORREPTION, SHORT_SYNIZESIS ]
 92CORREPTED_SYLLABLES = [ LONG_CORREPTION ]
 93CORREPTED_SYNIZESIS = [ LONG_CORREPTION, INDETERMINATE_CORREPTION ]
 94SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES = [ SHORT_SYNIZESIS ]
 95ALL_SYLLABLES = [ LONG, SHORT, INDETERMINATE, LONG_CORREPTION, INDETERMINATE_CORREPTION, SHORT_SYNIZESIS ]
 96
 97class ScansionNFA:
 98    TRANSITION_TABLE = [
 99        #(from_state, accept_syllables,    to_state, cost, scan_as)
100
101        ###
102        ### first foot
103        ###
104
105        # long first syllable
106        ( 0,          LONG_SYLLABLES,      1,        0,    LONG),
107        ( 0,          SHORT_SYLLABLES,     1,        15,   LONG),
108        # synizesis producing long first syllable
109        ( 0,          SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 3,        1,    SKIPPED),
110        ( 3,          ALL_SYLLABLES,       1,        0,    LONG),
111        # long second syllable of spondee
112        ( 1,          LONG_SYLLABLES,      7,        0,    LONG + FOOT),
113        ( 1,          SHORT_SYLLABLES,     7,        15,   LONG + FOOT),
114        # synizesis producing long second syllable of spondee
115        ( 1,          SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 4,        1,    SKIPPED),
116        ( 4,          ALL_SYLLABLES,       7,        0,    LONG + FOOT),
117        # short second syllable of dactyl
118        ( 1,          SHORT_SYLLABLES,     2,        0,    SHORT),
119        ( 1,          CORREPTED_SYLLABLES, 2,        1,    SHORT),
120        # synizesis and correption producing short second syllable of dactyl
121        ( 1,          SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 5,        1,    SKIPPED),
122        ( 5,          CORREPTED_SYNIZESIS, 2,        1,    SHORT),
123        # short third syllable of dactyl
124        ( 2,          SHORT_SYLLABLES,     7,        0,    SHORT + FOOT),
125        ( 2,          CORREPTED_SYLLABLES, 7,        1,    SHORT + FOOT),
126        # synizesis and correption producins short third syllable of dactyl
127        ( 2,          SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 6,        1,    SKIPPED),
128        ( 6,          CORREPTED_SYNIZESIS, 7,        1,    SHORT + FOOT),
129
130        ###
131        ### second foot
132        ###
133
134        # long first syllable
135        ( 7,          LONG_SYLLABLES,      8,        0,    LONG),
136        ( 7,          SHORT_SYLLABLES,     8,        15,   LONG),
137        # synizesis producing long first syllable
138        ( 7,          SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 10,       1,    SKIPPED),
139        ( 10,         ALL_SYLLABLES,       8,        0,    LONG),
140        # long second syllable of spondee
141        ( 8,          LONG_SYLLABLES,      14,       0,    LONG + FOOT),
142        ( 8,          SHORT_SYLLABLES,     14,       15,   LONG + FOOT),
143        # synizesis producing long second syllable of spondee
144        ( 8,          SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 11,       1,    SKIPPED),
145        ( 11,         ALL_SYLLABLES,       14,       0,    LONG + FOOT),
146        # short second syllable of dactyl
147        ( 8,          SHORT_SYLLABLES,     9,        0,    SHORT),
148        ( 8,          CORREPTED_SYLLABLES, 9,        1,    SHORT),
149        # synizesis and correption producing short second syllable of dactyl
150        ( 8,          SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 12,       1,    SKIPPED),
151        ( 12,         CORREPTED_SYNIZESIS, 9,        1,    SHORT),
152        # short third syllable of dactyl
153        ( 9,          SHORT_SYLLABLES,     14,       0,    SHORT + FOOT),
154        ( 9,          CORREPTED_SYLLABLES, 14,       1,    SHORT + FOOT),
155        # synizesis and correption producins short third syllable of dactyl
156        ( 9,          SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 13,       1,    SKIPPED),
157        ( 13,         CORREPTED_SYNIZESIS, 14,       1,    SHORT + FOOT),
158
159        ###
160        ### third foot
161        ###
162
163        # long first syllable
164        ( 14,         LONG_SYLLABLES,      15,       0,    LONG),
165        ( 14,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     15,       15,   LONG),
166        # synizesis producing long first syllable
167        ( 14,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 17,       1,    SKIPPED),
168        ( 17,         ALL_SYLLABLES,       15,       0,    LONG),
169        # long second syllable of spondee
170        ( 15,         LONG_SYLLABLES,      21,       0,    LONG + FOOT),
171        ( 15,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     21,       15,   LONG + FOOT),
172        # synizesis producing long second syllable of spondee
173        ( 15,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 18,       1,    SKIPPED),
174        ( 18,         ALL_SYLLABLES,       21,       0,    LONG + FOOT),
175        # short second syllable of dactyl
176        ( 15,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     16,       0,    SHORT),
177        ( 15,         CORREPTED_SYLLABLES, 16,       1,    SHORT),
178        # synizesis and correption producing short second syllable of dactyl
179        ( 15,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 19,       1,    SKIPPED),
180        ( 19,         CORREPTED_SYNIZESIS, 16,       1,    SHORT),
181        # short third syllable of dactyl
182        ( 16,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     21,       0,    SHORT + FOOT),
183        ( 16,         CORREPTED_SYLLABLES, 21,       1,    SHORT + FOOT),
184        # synizesis and correption producins short third syllable of dactyl
185        ( 16,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 20,       1,    SKIPPED),
186        ( 20,         CORREPTED_SYNIZESIS, 21,       1,    SHORT + FOOT),
187
188        ###
189        ### fourth foot
190        ###
191
192        # long first syllable
193        ( 21,         LONG_SYLLABLES,      22,       0,    LONG),
194        ( 21,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     22,       15,   LONG),
195        # synizesis producing long first syllable
196        ( 21,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 24,       1,    SKIPPED),
197        ( 24,         ALL_SYLLABLES,       22,       0,    LONG),
198        # long second syllable of spondee
199        ( 22,         LONG_SYLLABLES,      28,       0,    LONG + FOOT),
200        ( 22,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     28,       15,   LONG + FOOT),
201        # synizesis producing long second syllable of spondee
202        ( 22,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 25,       1,    SKIPPED),
203        ( 25,         ALL_SYLLABLES,       28,       0,    LONG + FOOT),
204        # short second syllable of dactyl
205        ( 22,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     23,       0,    SHORT),
206        ( 22,         CORREPTED_SYLLABLES, 23,       1,    SHORT),
207        # synizesis and correption producing short second syllable of dactyl
208        ( 22,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 26,       1,    SKIPPED),
209        ( 26,         CORREPTED_SYNIZESIS, 23,       1,    SHORT),
210        # short third syllable of dactyl
211        ( 23,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     28,       0,    SHORT + FOOT),
212        ( 23,         CORREPTED_SYLLABLES, 28,       1,    SHORT + FOOT),
213        # synizesis and correption producins short third syllable of dactyl
214        ( 23,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 27,       1,    SKIPPED),
215        ( 27,         CORREPTED_SYNIZESIS, 28,       1,    SHORT + FOOT),
216
217        ###
218        ### fifth foot
219        ###
220
221        # NOTE: We tend to prefer a dactylic fifth foot, so raise the cost
222        # of spondees for this foot only.
223
224        # long first syllable
225        ( 28,         LONG_SYLLABLES,      29,       0,    LONG),
226        ( 28,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     29,       15,   LONG),
227        # synizesis producing long first syllable
228        ( 28,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 31,       1,    SKIPPED),
229        ( 31,         ALL_SYLLABLES,       29,       0,    LONG),
230        # long second syllable of spondee
231        ( 29,         LONG_SYLLABLES,      35,       1,    LONG + FOOT), # raised spondee cost
232        ( 29,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     35,       16,   LONG + FOOT),
233        # synizesis producing long second syllable of spondee
234        ( 29,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 32,       1,    SKIPPED),
235        ( 32,         ALL_SYLLABLES,       35,       1,    LONG + FOOT), # raised spondee cost
236        # short second syllable of dactyl
237        ( 29,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     30,       0,    SHORT),
238        ( 29,         CORREPTED_SYLLABLES, 30,       1,    SHORT),
239        # synizesis and correption producing short second syllable of dactyl
240        ( 29,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 33,       1,    SKIPPED),
241        ( 33,         CORREPTED_SYNIZESIS, 30,       1,    SHORT),
242        # short third syllable of dactyl
243        ( 30,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     35,       0,    SHORT + FOOT),
244        ( 30,         CORREPTED_SYLLABLES, 35,       1,    SHORT + FOOT),
245        # synizesis and correption producins short third syllable of dactyl
246        ( 30,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 34,       1,    SKIPPED),
247        ( 34,         CORREPTED_SYNIZESIS, 35,       1,    SHORT + FOOT),
248
249        ###
250        ### sixth foot
251        ###
252
253        # long first syllable
254        ( 35,         LONG_SYLLABLES,      36,       0,    LONG),
255        ( 35,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     36,       15,   LONG),
256        # synizesis producing long first syllable
257        ( 35,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 38,       1,    SKIPPED),
258        ( 38,         ALL_SYLLABLES,       36,       0,    LONG),
259        # any second syllable
260        ( 36,         ALL_SYLLABLES,       37,       0,    LONG),
261        # synizesis producing long second syllable
262        ( 36,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 39,       1,    SKIPPED),
263        ( 39,         ALL_SYLLABLES,       37,       0,    LONG),
264    ]
265    START_STATE = 0
266    ACCEPT_STATE = 37 # only at end of input
267
268    transitions = defaultdict(list)
269    for from_state, syllables, to_state, cost, scan_as in TRANSITION_TABLE:
270        for syllable in syllables:
271            transitions[(from_state, syllable)].append((to_state, cost, scan_as))
272
273    def __init__(self):
274        self.states = [ (self.START_STATE, 0, '') ] # state, cost, scansion
275
276    def input(self, syllables):
277        for syllable in syllables:
278            self.transition(syllable)
279
280    def transition(self, syllable):
281        new_states = []
282        for old_state, old_cost, old_scansion in self.states:
283            transitions = self.transitions[(old_state, syllable)]
284            for new_state, path_cost, path_scansion in transitions:
285                new_cost = old_cost + path_cost
286                new_scansion = old_scansion + (path_scansion or '')
287                new_states.append((new_state, new_cost, new_scansion))
288
289        self.states = new_states
290
291    def results(self):
292        return sorted([(s[1], s[2]) for s in self.states
293                      if s[0] == self.ACCEPT_STATE])
294
295
296def normalize(scansion):
297    nfa = ScansionNFA()
298    nfa.input(scansion)
299    return nfa.results()
LONG = '+'
SHORT = '-'
INDETERMINATE = '?'
LONG_CORREPTION = 'C'
INDETERMINATE_CORREPTION = 'c'
SHORT_SYNIZESIS = ','
SKIPPED = '.'
FOOT = '|'
LONG_SYLLABLES = ['+', '?', 'C', 'c']
SHORT_SYLLABLES = ['-', '?', 'c', ',']
CORREPTED_SYLLABLES = ['C']
CORREPTED_SYNIZESIS = ['C', 'c']
SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES = [',']
ALL_SYLLABLES = ['+', '-', '?', 'C', 'c', ',']
class ScansionNFA: 
 98class ScansionNFA:
 99    TRANSITION_TABLE = [
100        #(from_state, accept_syllables,    to_state, cost, scan_as)
101
102        ###
103        ### first foot
104        ###
105
106        # long first syllable
107        ( 0,          LONG_SYLLABLES,      1,        0,    LONG),
108        ( 0,          SHORT_SYLLABLES,     1,        15,   LONG),
109        # synizesis producing long first syllable
110        ( 0,          SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 3,        1,    SKIPPED),
111        ( 3,          ALL_SYLLABLES,       1,        0,    LONG),
112        # long second syllable of spondee
113        ( 1,          LONG_SYLLABLES,      7,        0,    LONG + FOOT),
114        ( 1,          SHORT_SYLLABLES,     7,        15,   LONG + FOOT),
115        # synizesis producing long second syllable of spondee
116        ( 1,          SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 4,        1,    SKIPPED),
117        ( 4,          ALL_SYLLABLES,       7,        0,    LONG + FOOT),
118        # short second syllable of dactyl
119        ( 1,          SHORT_SYLLABLES,     2,        0,    SHORT),
120        ( 1,          CORREPTED_SYLLABLES, 2,        1,    SHORT),
121        # synizesis and correption producing short second syllable of dactyl
122        ( 1,          SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 5,        1,    SKIPPED),
123        ( 5,          CORREPTED_SYNIZESIS, 2,        1,    SHORT),
124        # short third syllable of dactyl

202        # synizesis producing long second syllable of spondee

205        # short second syllable of dactyl

207        ( 22,         CORREPTED_SYLLABLES, 23,       1,    SHORT),
208        # synizesis and correption producing short second syllable of dactyl
209        ( 22,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 26,       1,    SKIPPED),
210        ( 26,         CORREPTED_SYNIZESIS, 23,       1,    SHORT),
211        # short third syllable of dactyl
212        ( 23,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     28,       0,    SHORT + FOOT),
213        ( 23,         CORREPTED_SYLLABLES, 28,       1,    SHORT + FOOT),
214        # synizesis and correption producins short third syllable of dactyl
215        ( 23,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 27,       1,    SKIPPED),
216        ( 27,         CORREPTED_SYNIZESIS, 28,       1,    SHORT + FOOT),
217
218        ###
219        ### fifth foot
220        ###
221
222        # NOTE: We tend to prefer a dactylic fifth foot, so raise the cost
223        # of spondees for this foot only.
224
225        # long first syllable
226        ( 28,         LONG_SYLLABLES,      29,       0,    LONG),
227        ( 28,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     29,       15,   LONG),
228        # synizesis producing long first syllable
229        ( 28,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 31,       1,    SKIPPED),
230        ( 31,         ALL_SYLLABLES,       29,       0,    LONG),
231        # long second syllable of spondee
232        ( 29,         LONG_SYLLABLES,      35,       1,    LONG + FOOT), # raised spondee cost
233        ( 29,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     35,       16,   LONG + FOOT),
234        # synizesis producing long second syllable of spondee
235        ( 29,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 32,       1,    SKIPPED),
236        ( 32,         ALL_SYLLABLES,       35,       1,    LONG + FOOT), # raised spondee cost
237        # short second syllable of dactyl
238        ( 29,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     30,       0,    SHORT),
239        ( 29,         CORREPTED_SYLLABLES, 30,       1,    SHORT),
240        # synizesis and correption producing short second syllable of dactyl
241        ( 29,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 33,       1,    SKIPPED),
242        ( 33,         CORREPTED_SYNIZESIS, 30,       1,    SHORT),
243        # short third syllable of dactyl
244        ( 30,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     35,       0,    SHORT + FOOT),
245        ( 30,         CORREPTED_SYLLABLES, 35,       1,    SHORT + FOOT),
246        # synizesis and correption producins short third syllable of dactyl
247        ( 30,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 34,       1,    SKIPPED),
248        ( 34,         CORREPTED_SYNIZESIS, 35,       1,    SHORT + FOOT),
249
250        ###
251        ### sixth foot
252        ###
253
254        # long first syllable
255        ( 35,         LONG_SYLLABLES,      36,       0,    LONG),
256        ( 35,         SHORT_SYLLABLES,     36,       15,   LONG),
257        # synizesis producing long first syllable
258        ( 35,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 38,       1,    SKIPPED),
259        ( 38,         ALL_SYLLABLES,       36,       0,    LONG),
260        # any second syllable
261        ( 36,         ALL_SYLLABLES,       37,       0,    LONG),
262        # synizesis producing long second syllable
263        ( 36,         SYNIZESIS_SYLLABLES, 39,       1,    SKIPPED),
264        ( 39,         ALL_SYLLABLES,       37,       0,    LONG),
265    ]
266    START_STATE = 0
267    ACCEPT_STATE = 37 # only at end of input
268
269    transitions = defaultdict(list)
270    for from_state, syllables, to_state, cost, scan_as in TRANSITION_TABLE:
271        for syllable in syllables:
272            transitions[(from_state, syllable)].append((to_state, cost, scan_as))
273
274    def __init__(self):
275        self.states = [ (self.START_STATE, 0, '') ] # state, cost, scansion
276
277    def input(self, syllables):
278        for syllable in syllables:
279            self.transition(syllable)
280
281    def transition(self, syllable):
282        new_states = []
283        for old_state, old_cost, old_scansion in self.states:
284            transitions = self.transitions[(old_state, syllable)]
285            for new_state, path_cost, path_scansion in transitions:
286                new_cost = old_cost + path_cost
287                new_scansion = old_scansion + (path_scansion or '')
288                new_states.append((new_state, new_cost, new_scansion))
289
290        self.states = new_states
291
292    def results(self):
293        return sorted([(s[1], s[2]) for s in self.states
294                      if s[0] == self.ACCEPT_STATE])

states
def input(self, syllables): 
277    def input(self, syllables):
278        for syllable in syllables:
279            self.transition(syllable)
def transition(self, syllable): 
281    def transition(self, syllable):
282        new_states = []
283        for old_state, old_cost, old_scansion in self.states:
284            transitions = self.transitions[(old_state, syllable)]
285            for new_state, path_cost, path_scansion in transitions:
286                new_cost = old_cost + path_cost
287                new_scansion = old_scansion + (path_scansion or '')
288                new_states.append((new_state, new_cost, new_scansion))
289
290        self.states = new_states
def results(self): 
292    def results(self):
293        return sorted([(s[1], s[2]) for s in self.states
294                      if s[0] == self.ACCEPT_STATE])
from_state = 39
syllables = ['+', '-', '?', 'C', 'c', ',']
to_state = 37
cost = 0
scan_as = '+'
syllable = ','
def normalize(scansion): 
297def normalize(scansion):
298    nfa = ScansionNFA()
299    nfa.input(scansion)
300    return nfa.results()
